newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysian govt not a stupid investor - Mahathir.
newsitem.headline: Malaysian govt not a stupid investor - Mahathir.

text.p: Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said on Thursday his government did not invest stupidly in foreign projects as presumed by some critics, and had scored some major business coups overseas.
"We're not as stupid as we're thought to be," Mahathir told reporters.
A member of parliament this week questioned whether the state investment agency Khazanah Nasional had taken too much risk in backing the YTL Corp bid to buy a Hong Kong power company.

Khazanah had agreed to provide a $1 billion loan to YTL, a state-run infrastructure and power company, to buy a controlling stake in Hong Kong's Consolidated Electric Power Asia Ltd (CEPA) But YTL said on Tuesday that the deal, which would have cost it a total of $2.6 billion, was aborted.
Mahathir defended Khazanah, saying the firm had calculated its risk in the deal and even planned to be a substantial shareholder in CEPA in return for the loan extended to YTL.
"If this had happened, we'd be in control of a giant power firm represented in countries such as Indonesia, China, the Philippines and Pakistan," said Mahathir.
"Give us some faith, please," he added. "There are lots of things we do that appear stupid but aren't actually. This was one good deal that got away."
